title: Question: How to use depends_on w/out caring about variants.
body:
I'm working on a package (cask) that depends_on('emacs').  I have emacs installed w/out X:

```
[throgg@spack-central spack]$ spack find -v emacs
==> 1 installed packages.
-- linux-centos7-x86_64 / gcc@5.4.0 -----------------------------
emacs@24.5~X~gtkplus
```

Cask ends up wanting emacs _with_ X, which won't work (stripped remote access machine).

```
[throgg@spack-central spack]$ spack spec cask
Input spec
------------------------------
  cask

Normalized
------------------------------
  cask
      ^emacs
          ^ncurses

Concretized
------------------------------
  cask@0.7.4%gcc@5.4.0 arch=linux-centos7-x86_64
      ^emacs@24.5%gcc@5.4.0+X~gtkplus arch=linux-centos7-x86_64
          ^giflib@5.1.4%gcc@5.4.0 arch=linux-centos7-x86_64
          ^libpng@1.6.16%gcc@5.4.0 arch=linux-centos7-x86_64
              ^zlib@1.2.8%gcc@5.4.0 arch=linux-centos7-x86_64
          ^libtiff@4.0.3%gcc@5.4.0 arch=linux-centos7-x86_64
              ^jpeg@9b%gcc@5.4.0 arch=linux-centos7-x86_64
              ^xz@5.2.2%gcc@5.4.0 arch=linux-centos7-x86_64
          ^libxpm@3.5.11%gcc@5.4.0 arch=linux-centos7-x86_64
          ^ncurses@6.0%gcc@5.4.0 arch=linux-centos7-x86_64
```

I think that this is because the X variant in the emacs package defaults to `True`.

I expected a dependency on a package w/out a variant spec to essentially wildcard that variant when it was concretized.

Is there a way to specify a dependency w/out regard to variants?  I don't see any mention in [the dependencies section of the packaging guide](http://software.llnl.gov/spack/packaging_guide.html#dependencies).
